migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Mohan Chopra|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Mohan Chopra | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1921|09|10}} | birth_place = [[Gurdaspur]], [[India]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1969|12|11|1921|09|10}} | death_place = | nationality = Punjabi | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Intellectual and author }}
'''Mohan Chopra''' (10 September 1921 – 11 December 1969) was a [[Hindi]] intellectual and author.
==Life== Mohan Chopra was born at [[Gurdaspur]], [[Punjab (India)|Punjab]], [[India]]. He received his education at [[Dalhousie, India|Dalhousie]], Gurdaspur, and [[Lahore]]. He earned an M.A. in English and taught in colleges at Lahore, [[Ludhiana]], [[Ferozepur]], and [[Hisar, India|Hissar]].
==Works== ===Short stories=== Chopra's first short story was published in 1953 in a [[Kolkata|Calcuttan]] magazine called ''Ranee''. He wrote about a hundred short stories in his life. Most of them were published in a magazine from [[Allahabad]] called ''Kahani''. These stories are included in several collections of short stories titled ''Aadha Kata Hua Surya'', ''Peele Patte'', ''Sham Aur Akela Aadmi'', ''Band Darwaza'', ''Intezaar Aur Terah Anya Kahaniyan'' and ''Mohan Chopra ki Shresth Kahaniyan''. A number of these short stories have been translated in other Indian languages.
====Novels==== Mohan Chopra's novel, ''Bahein'', was published in 1956. Thereafter, five other novels were published: ''Needh Se Aage'', ''Ek Chhaya Aur Main'', ''Subah Se Pahle'', ''Ye Naye Log'', and ''Tuta Hua Aadmi''. ''Ek Chhaya Aur Main'' was translated into the [[Kannada]] language and published under the name ''Bhranti Samar''.
====Drama==== In the field of drama, three of Mohan Chopra's works were published: ''Samay Ke Swar'', a collection of one-act plays; ''Chattan Ka Phool'', a collection of radio plays; and ''Aandhi Aur Ghar'', a full-length play. ''Aandhi Aur Ghar'' was written along the lines of a Greek drama, keeping in view the unity of time, place, and action.
====Travelogue==== ''Vaadiyon Ke Raaste'', a travelogue, was published in 1968.
====Poetry==== Chopra published two books of poetry: ''Nai Subah Ke Charan'' in 1968 and ''Coffee House Mein Mynah'' in 2000.
===Subject of Ph.D research=== His works were the subject of extensive research by [[Kurukshetra University]]. In 2000, a Ph.D degree was awarded to Promila Anand for research work entitled ''Mohan Chopra Ka Vyaktitava Aur Krititava''. In 2009, another Ph.D degree was awarded to Seema Devi for her research work entitled ''Mohan Chopra Ke Sahitya Mein Vyakt Jeewan Darshan''. His works were also the subject of many M. Phil degrees awarded by [[Kurukshetra]] and [[Guru Nanak Dev]] Universities.
===Awards=== His novels ''Tuta Hua Aadmi'' and ''Ye Naye Log'', the full-length play ''Aandhi Aur Ghar'', and collection of short stories ''Aadha Kata Hua Surya'' were declared the best works of the year for 1971, 1972, and 1973 respectively by the Haryana Government.<ref name=haryana>Department of Languages, Haryana State Government, India</ref> His novel ''Ye Naye Log'' was declared the best work for the year 1972 by the Punjab Government.<ref name=punjab>Department of Languages, Punjab State Government, India</ref>
==Mohan Chopra's works in chronological order== *''Samay Ke Swar'', a collection of one-act plays, 1955<ref name=nava>Published by "Nava Sahitya Prakashan", Multani Dhanda, New Delhi-1</ref> *''Baahein'', a novel, 1956<ref name=nava /> *''Needh Se Aage'', a novel, 1961<ref name=Aatma>Published by "Aatma Ram & Sons",Delhi-6</ref> *''Chattan Ka Phool'', a collection of radio plays, 1963<ref name="Aatma"/> *''Ek Chhaya Aur Main'', a novel, 1965<ref name=Hind>Published by "Hind Pocket Books", Delhi-6</ref> *''Nai Subah Ke Charan'', a collection of poems, 1967<ref name=Modern>Published by "Modern Publications", Ambala Cantt</ref> *''Vaadiyon Ke Raaste'', a travelogue, 1968<ref name=Aalok>Published by "Aalok Prakashan", Kurukshetra</ref> *''Subah Se Pahle'', a novel, 1969<ref name=Rajpal>Published by "Rajpal and Sons", Delhi-6</ref> *''Ye Naye Log'', a novel, 1970<ref name="Aatma"/> *''Tuta Hua Aadmi'', a novel, 1971<ref name=Vish>Published by "Vishvodaya Prakashan", Delhi-9</ref> *''Aandhi Aur Ghar'', a full-length play, 1972<ref name="Vish"/> *''Aadha Kata Hua Surya'', a collection of short stories, 1973<ref name="Vish"/> *''Peele Patte, Sham Aur Akela Aadmi'', a collection of short stories,1987<ref name=Aasha>Published by "Aasha Prakashan Greh", New Delhi-5</ref> *''Band Darwaja'', a collection of short stories, 1990<ref name="Aasha"/> *''Coffee House Main Mynah'', a collection of poems, 2000<ref name=Arya>Published by "Arya Book Depot", New Delhi-5</ref> *''Intezaar Aur Terah Anya Kahaaniyan'', a collection of short stories, 2002<ref name="Arya"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://openlibrary.org/a/OL15977A?m=view&v=4 Books by Mohan Chopra]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chopra, Mohan}} [[Category:Hindi-language writers]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]]

'''Muireadhach Albanach Ó Dálaigh''' ("Scottish Muireadhach") was a [[Gaels|Gaelic]] [[poet]] and [[crusade]]r and member of the [[Ó Dálaigh]] bardic family.
==Early career== ''[[Annals of the Four Masters|The Annals of the Four Masters of Ireland]]'', s.a. 1213, tells us that he was the [[ollamh]] (high poet) of Domhnall Ó Domhnaill (died 1241). Muireadhach lived in [[Lissadell]] in [[Cairbre Drom Cliabh]], now [[County Sligo]] and fled from [[Ireland]] after killing King Domhnall's tax-collector Fionn Ó Brolacháin, whom Muireadhach considered had been insolent, with an axe.<ref>The ''Annals of the Four Masters'', s.a. 1213.8-9, [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/G100005C/text005.html text] and [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100005C/text005.html translation]; see also McLeod, ''op. cit.'', pp. 85-6.</ref>
In a poem, Ó Dálaigh dismisses his murder as his victim was a mere commoner and therefore of no account, a telling indication of the rigid stratification of traditional Irish society:
<poem style="margin-left:2em"> Trifling is our difference with the man, A shepherd was affronting me; And I killed that clown; O God! Is this a cause for enmity?<ref>Mangan, p. 7.</ref> </poem>
==Career in Scotland== Nevertheless, it was in Scotland that Muireadhach made his name. He served as the court bard to the [[Mormaer of Lennox]]. The specific [[mormaer]] who patronized him is often thought to have been [[Ailín II, Earl of Lennox|Ailín II]] (died 1217), but as the mormaer is called "Mac Muireadhach", son of Muireadhach, it was almost certainly in fact his predecessor and father, [[Ailín I, Earl of Lennox|Ailín I]] (died c. 1200).<ref>McLeod, ''op. cit.'', p. 86; , Thomas Owen (ed.) Clancy''The Triumph Tree: Scotland's Earliest Poetry, 550–1350'', (Edinburgh, 1998), p. 258.</ref> Muireadhach Albanach is important for the cultural history of Scotland because he is the alleged founder of the family of hereditary Scottish bards known to history as the ''[[MacMhuirich bardic family|Mac Mhuireadhaich]]'' or "MacVurich" family.<ref>MacQuarrie, ''Scotland and the Crusades'', (Edinburgh, 1997), p. 37.</ref>
==The Fifth Crusade== Muireadhach, like his fellow Gaelic poet [[Gillebrìghde Albanach]], went on the [[Fifth Crusade]] and travelled to [[Acre (city)|Acre]] and [[Damietta]] (as well as other places, like [[Rome]]). In 1228 he was apparently allowed to re-enter [[Ireland]].<ref>MacQuarrie, ''op. cit.'', p. 39.</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * O'Daly, Edmund Emmet, ''History of the O'Dalys'' (Tuttle Morehouse & Taylor Publ. Co., New Haven, Conn., USA, 1937) * Thomson, Professor Derick, ''The MacMhurich bardic family'' in ''Transactions of the Gaelic Society of Inverness'' 43 (1960–63) * Gillies, William, ''A Death-bed poem ascribed to Muireadhach Albanach'', ''Celtica'' 21 (1990) * MacQuarrie, Alan, ''Scotland and the Crusades'', (Edinburgh, 1997) * Clancy, Thomas Owen (ed.), ''The Triumph Tree: Scotland's Earliest Poetry, 550–1350'', (Edinburgh, 1998) * McLeod, Wilson, ''Divided Gaels: Gaelic Cultural Identities in Scotland and Ireland, c. 1200-1650'', (Oxford, 2004) *Mangan, J.C. (trans.) (1852) ''The Tribes of Ireland: a Satire.'' by Aenghus O'Daly, with poetical tr. by J. C. Mangan; together with An historical account of the family of O'Daly; and an introduction to the history of satire in Ireland, by J. O'Donovan, Dublin. [https://books.google.com/books?id=kpiS0ZP5yRwC&pg=PA42&dq=Daly+Dunsandle&lr=&as_brr=3#PPA1,M1]
==External links== * [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/G100005C/text005.html ''The Annals of the Four Masters of Ireland'', s.a. 1213] ** [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100005C/text005.html Translation] {{Ó Dálaigh}} {{Irish poetry}}
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{About|the colloquial slang|the racial slur|Nigger|the singer also known as "Nigga"|Flex (singer)}}
{{pp-semi-indef}}{{pp-move-indef}} '''''Nigga''''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|ɪ|ɡ|ə}}) is a [[Colloquialism|colloquial]] term used in [[African-American Vernacular English]] that began as an [[eye dialect]] form of the word ''[[nigger]]'', an [[list of ethnic slurs|ethnic slur]] against [[black people]]. In some dialects of English, the word is pronounced the same as ''nigger'' in [[Rhoticity in English|non-rhotic]] speech.
== Usage == In practice, its use and meaning are heavily dependent on context.<ref name=WP>Randall Kennedy. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/books/chap1/nigger.htm Nigger: The Strange Career of a Troublesome Word], ''Pantheon''. 256 pp</ref> Presently, the word ''nigga'' is used more liberally among younger members of all [[Race (classification of humans)|races]] and [[ethnicities]] in the [[United States]].<ref name =BBC>Jeremy Cooke. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6406625.stm Racial slur banned in New York,] ''BBC News'', 1 March 2007</ref> In addition to [[African Americans|African America]], other ethnic groups have adopted the term as part of their vernacular.<ref name=ENQ>Kevin Aldridge, Richelle Thompson and Earnest Winston. "[http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2001/08/05/loc_1the_n-word.html The evolving N-word]." ''The Cincinnati Enquirer'', August 5, 2001.</ref><ref name=LCM>Kendra Pierre. [http://www.lcmeridian.com/media/storage/paper806/news/2006/05/01/News/nigger.nigga.Or.Neither-1876412.shtml?norewrite200610170024&sourcedomain=www.lcmeridian.com 'Nigger,' 'Nigga' or Neither?], ''Meridia'', May 1, 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309080959/http://www.lcmeridian.com/media/storage/paper806/news/2006/05/01/News/nigger.nigga.Or.Neither-1876412.shtml?norewrite200610170024&sourcedomain=www.lcmeridian.com |date=March 9, 2009 }}</ref>
There is conflicting popular opinion on whether there is any meaningful difference between ''nigga'' and ''nigger'' as a spoken term.<ref name=Metro>J. Douglas Allen-Taylor. [http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/04.09.98/cover/nigger-9814.html New Word Order], ''Metro'', April 9, 1998.</ref> Many people consider the terms to be equally [[pejorative]], and the use of ''nigga'' both in and outside black communities remains controversial.<ref name=SGM>Alex Alonso. [https://archive.is/20130104234128/http://www.streetgangs.com/magazine/053003niggas.php Won’t You Please Be My Nigga: Double Standards with a Taboo Word], May 30, 2003.</ref> H. Lewis Smith, author of ''Bury that Sucka: A Scandalous Affair with the N-word'', believes that "replacing the 'er' with an 'a' changes nothing other than the pronunciation"<ref>Smith. H. Lewis.[http://www.blackcommentator.com/214/214_n_word_not_just_another_smith_guest.html "Why The N-word Is Not Just Another Word]." ''The Black Commentator.'' January 25, 2007. Issue 214. Retrieved 01-26-2007.</ref> and the ''African American Registry'' notes, "Brother (Brotha) and Sister (Sistah or Sista) are terms of endearment. Nigger was and still is a word of disrespect."<ref>Phil Middleton and David Pilgrim, [http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/nigger-word-brief-history "Nigger (the word), a brief history!]." ''African American Registry.'' 2001. Retrieved 03-14-2007.</ref> The [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]], a civil rights group, condemns use of both ''nigga'' and ''nigger''.<ref name=Metro />
Some African-Americans only consider ''nigga'' offensive when used by people of other races,<ref name=Metro/> seeing its use outside a [[speech community|defined social group]] as an unwelcome [[cultural appropriation]]. Used by blacks, the term may indicate "solidarity or affection",<ref name=ENQ2>Kevin Aldridge. [http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2001/08/05/loc_2slurs_often_adopted.html Slurs often adopted by those they insult], ''The Cincinnati Enquirer'', August 5, 2001.</ref> similar to the usage of the words ''[[dude]]'', ''[[Homie|homeboy]]'', and ''bro''. Others consider "nigga" non-offensive except when directed from a non-African-American towards an African-American. Yet others have derided this as hypocritical and harmful, enabling white racists to use the word and confusing the issue over ''nigger''.<ref name=ENQ/>
== Cultural influence == The term "nigga, please", used in the 1970s by comics such as [[Paul Mooney (comedian)|Paul Mooney]] as "a funny punctuation in jokes about Blacks",<ref name=Mooney>Darryl Fears. [http://www.bet.com/Entertainment/jacksonmooneynwordboycott.htm?Referrer=%7B03CE5360-2620-42CB-AD7E-77E4249C5FB7%7D Jesse Jackson, Paul Mooney Call for End of N-Word], ''BET.com'', November 27, 2006.</ref>{{nicg|date=January 2018}} is now heard routinely in comedy routines by African Americans. The growing use of the term is often attributed to its ubiquity in modern American [[hip hop music]].<ref name=WASH>Darryl Fears. "Patent offense: Wayans's hip-hop line", ''The Washington Post'', March 15, 2006.</ref><ref name=Wired>Rogers Cadenhead. "[https://www.wired.com/news/technology/0,70259-0.html Actor Tries to Trademark 'N' Word]", ''Wired'', 23 February 2006.</ref> Examples include: *[[N.W.A|Niggaz Wit Attitudes]] (N.W.A) *[[A Tribe Called Quest]]'s "Sucka Nigga" *[[Notorious B.I.G.]]'s "The Realest Niggaz" *[[Jay-Z]]'s "[[Jigga That Nigga]]" and "[[Nigga What, Nigga Who (Originator 99)]]" *Jay-Z and [[Kanye West]]'s "[[Niggas in Paris]]" *[[DJ Khaled]]'s "[[I Wish You Would (DJ Khaled song)|I Wish You Would]]" *[[Snoop Dogg]]'s "For All My Niggaz and Bitches" *[[Nicki Minaj]]'s "[[Lookin Ass]]" *Kanye West's "[[All Day (Kanye West song)|All Day]]" *[[YG (rapper)|YG's]] "[[My Nigga]]" *[[Bobby Shmurda]]'s "[[Hot Nigga]]"
One of the earliest uses of the term in a popular song was the 1983 song ''[[New York New York (Grandmaster Flash song)|New York New York]]'' by [[Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five]], although it had featured in some very early hip hop recordings such as ''Scoopy Rap'' and ''Family Rap'', both from 1979. [[Ol' Dirty Bastard]] uses the term 76 times in his ''[[Nigga Please]]'' album (not including repetitions in choruses).<ref name=Wired/>
Comedian [[Chris Rock]]'s routine "[[Niggas vs. Black People]]" distinguishes a ''nigga'', which he defined as a "low-expectation-having [[motherfucker]]", from a "black person". In contrast, [[Tupac Shakur]] distinguished between ''nigger'' and ''nigga'': "Niggers was the [[lynching|ones on the rope]], hanging off the thing; niggas is the ones with [[Bling-bling|gold ropes]], hanging out at clubs."<ref>{{cite news |title=Interview with Tabitha Soren | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ljSCZyv97FY}}</ref> Tupac, who has been credited with legitimizing the term, said his song N.I.G.G.A. stood for "Never Ignorant Getting Goals Accomplished".<ref>{{cite news |title=Racial slur takes center stage at Stillman |author=Desiree Hunter |newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]] |location=Tuscaloosa, AL |date=24 February 2007 |url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20070224/NEWS/702240362?p=3&tc=pg |quote=Rapper Tupac Shakur was credited with legitimizing the term 'nigga' when he came out with the song 'N.I.G.G.A.', which he said stood for 'Never Ignorant Getting Goals Accomplished'.}}</ref>
== Use in trademarks or brand names == Until a 2017 ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court in ''[[Matal v. Tam]]'',<ref>{{cite web |first=Joe |last=Mullin |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/06/supreme-court-rules-offensive-trademarks-must-be-allowed/ |title=Supreme Court rules: Offensive trademarks must be allowed |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=19 June 2017 |access-date=19 June 2017 |publisher=[[Condé Nast]]}}</ref> the [[Lanham Act]] did not permit registration of [[trademark]]s containing terms that may [[Disparagement|disparage]] persons or bring them into disrepute.<ref>{{UnitedStatesCode|15|1052}}.</ref> Registration by the [[U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] (PTO) of terms that are historically considered disparaging to groups of people has been allowed in some circumstances. Self-disparaging trademarks have been allowed in some cases where the applicant has shown that the mark as-used is not considered by the relevant group to be disparaging.<ref name="Anten">{{Cite journal |last=Anten |first=Todd |title=Self-Disparaging Trademarks and Social Change: Factoring the Reappropriation of Slurs into Section 2(A) of the Lanham Act |journal=[[Columbia Law Review]] |volume=106 |page=338 |date=1 March 2006 |format=PDF |url=http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/106/2/Anten-Web.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726034928/http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/106/2/Anten-Web.pdf |archive-date=26 July 2011}}</ref>
In 1995, two [[Houston]], [[Texas]] men filed a trademark application with the PTO for the words "Naturally Intelligent God Gifted Africans", and its [[Acronym and initialism|acronym]]. The application was rejected, as were numerous subsequent applications for variations of the word "nigga". Most recently, comedian [[Damon Wayans]] twice attempted to trademark a [[brand name]] called Nigga, "featuring clothing, books, music and general merchandise".<ref name=WASH/> The PTO refused the application, stating "the very fact that debate is ongoing regarding in-[ethnic]-group usage, shows that a substantial composite of African Americans find the term 'nigga' to be offensive".<ref name=Wired/>
== See also == {{Portalbar|African-American|Language}} *''[[Guilty or Innocent of Using the N Word]]'' *[[Reappropriation]] *[[Murzyn]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{Wiktionary|nigga}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100818035852/http://www.theroot.com/views/lets-make-deal-n-word "Let's Make a Deal on the N-Word: White folks will stop using it, and black folks will stop pretending that quoting it is saying it,"] [[John McWhorter]], ''[[The Root (magazine)|The Root]]''
{{Spoken Wikipedia|Wikipedia_Nigga_Final_Master.ogg|{{Start date|2008|11|14}}}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Mahakavi | name = Pandalam Kerala Varma | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Pandalam Kerala Varma.jpg | image_size = | alt = Pandalam Kerala Varma | caption = Pandalam Kerala Varma | birth_name = | birth_date = January 1879 | baptism_date = | birth_place = [[Pandalam]], India | death_date = June 1919 (age 40) | residence = | nationality = Indian | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Poet, publisher, teacher | years_active = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = ''Rugmamgadacharitham'', ''Vijayodayam'' | style = | home_town = | spouse = Ammukkutty Amma | partner = <!-- unmarried life partner; use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = Perinjeri Illathu Vishnu Namboothiri, Puthankoikkal Aswathynal Thanwangi Thamburatti | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }}
'''Kerala Varma''' (January 1879 – June 1919), most commonly known as '''Mahakavi Pandalam Kerala Varma''', was an Indian poet, scholar, and publisher. He was born at [[Pandalam]], and belonged to the Pandalam Royal Family. He wrote two [[mahakavya]]s, more than a hundred narrative poems, translations, and [[children's poetry]].<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> He is widely regarded as the author of the first complete mahakavya in [[Malayalam]].<ref name=KS/><ref name=Encyclopedia /> He was the owner and Chief Editor of ''Kavana Kaumudi'', the first Malayalam periodical, which was also the first to introduce special issues in Malayalam.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi />
==Personal life== Kerala Varma was born at Pandalam in 1879, to [[Puthuppally, Kottayam|Kottayam Puthuppally]] Thrikkonamangalam Desathu Perinjeri Illathu Vishnu Namboothiri and Puthankoikkal Aswathynal Thanwangi Thamburatti.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> He had two elder brothers and an elder sister.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> He also had two paternal half-brothers; Neythelloor Koikkal Makayiramnal Kerala Varma Thampuran (1846–1890) and Neythelloor Kottarathil Thrikkettanal Veera Kerala Varma Thampuran.<ref name=halfbro>{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram: Volume 4|year=1974|pages=714–715|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref> Makayiramnal Kerala Varma Thampuran was the author of ''Bhoothanatholbhavam'' [[ottamthullal|thullal]] and ''Aardra Maholsavam'' [[Champu|Sanskrit champu]].<ref name=halfbro /> Thrikkettanal Veera Kerala Varma Thampuran was the author of ''Rukmamgadacharitham'' Sanskrit poem and ''Banayuddham'' Sanskrit champu.<ref name=halfbro /> He was also the logical reasoning [[guru]] of Pandalam Kerala Varma.<ref name=halfbro /> Pandalam Kerala Varma's relative Malikathazhe Bharaninal Kerala Varma Thampuran (1823–1883) was an astrology and grammar expert.<ref name="Volume 4">{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram: Volume 4|year=1974|page=713|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref> It is believed that he had predicted that Pandalam Kerala Varma would become famous one day.<ref name="Volume 4" /> Another relative Vadakke Kottarathil Thiruvathiranal Raja Raja Varma Valiya Thampuran (1817–1902) was the author of the hymns ''Dharmasathru Sathakam'', ''Krishnaleela'', ''Devi Sthothram'', ''Sabarigireesa Sthothram'', and ''Pandalam Mahadeva Sathakam''.<ref name="Volume 4" /> He took care of Pandalam Kerala Varma's poetic practice and grammatical studies.<ref name="Volume 4" /> Thekkekkettil Kottarathil Athamnal Godavarma Valiya Thampuran (1840–1911) was the grammar guru of Pandalam Kerala Varma.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
Kerala Varma started learning the alphabet at age 3 from Pandalam Achutha Warrier. After Warrier's death, Avittomnal Rama Varma Thampuran became his guru. Kerala Varma learnt ''Siddha Roopam'', ''Sree Ramodantham'', and ''Amara Kosam'' by age 10.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Thereafter he studied the poems ''Sree Krishna Vilasam'', ''Naishadheeya Charitha'', ''Kiratharjuneeyam'' and plays like ''abhigijñānaśākuntalam''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> From age 17 to 24, he studied ''Vyulpathi Vadaparyantham'' logical reasoning and ''Praudamanoramantham'' grammatical lessons.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Kerala Varma's [[upanayana]] was completed at the age of 14. He started writing [[Sanskrit]] poems from age 12, and Malayalam poems from age 19. He was established as a poet by the age of 20. Beside poetry, he was also skilled in other activities. In his childhood, he made a striking clock and a cycle for use in water.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
Kerala Varma married Ammukkutty Amma in 1905. The couple had two sons and three daughters.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> In 1914, he joined [[SMV High School, Thiruvananthapuram]] as language teacher. He also bought a house at [[Kaithamukku]] and settled in Thiruvananthapuram. During this period, he along with [[Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer]] learnt grammar and rhetorical figures under the guidance of Thuravoor Narayana Shastri.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> He was appointed a member on the expert panel of the [[Maharaja of Travancore]] by the then king [[Moolam Thirunal|Moolam Thirunal Rama Varma]] and was granted 10 [[Indian rupee|rupees]] as salary.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> He was conferred "Kavi Thilakan" honour by the [[Kingdom of Cochin|King of Cochin]].
Kerala Varma used to visit [[Thiruvananthapuram]] every year during [[Navratri]] festival time and engage in literary discussions with [[Kerala Varma Valiya Koil Thampuran]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Kerala Varma Devan: Biography|year=1944|page=255|author=M. R. Balakrishna Warrier}}</ref> His last journey with Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer was to [[Kochi]] to receive the "Kavi Thilakan" honour.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Kerala Varma was friends with Kodungallur Kochunni Thampuran, Kochi Parikshith Thampuran, and Sahridaya Thilakan Rama Pisharody.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
Kerala Varma was disturbed by the unexpected deaths of his relatives and close associates in a short period. His guru Avittomnal Rama Varma Thampuran, mother, father, and brother Veera Kerala Varma Thampuran died in a span of six years.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Kerala Varma died in 1919 from fever known at that time as Bombay Fever.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> In 1979, a collection of his writings were reprinted and published in two volumes as 'selected works'.<ref>http://www.ayyappa.com/LiteratureAndArt.htm</ref>
==Literary career==
===Earlier works=== Kerala Varma's initial works were ''Sreekrishna Sthothram'', an [[astakam|ashtakam]] on [[Lord Ayyappa|Dharmasastha]], ''Kesadipada Sathakam'', and ''Rasavilasambhanam''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> His first work was published in ''Subhashini'' newspaper, [[Changanassery]] in 1898. It was the completion of a poetic puzzle ''Kunnennu Cholvathinu Kuttamaseshamundo'' by Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Later he published his poems in ''Malayala Manorama'', ''Rasika Ranjini'', ''Kavitha Vilasini'', ''Dakshina Deepam'', ''Vijnana Ratnakaram'', ''Kerala Varma'', ''Kerala Kesari'', ''Bhasha Sarada'', ''Sumangala'', ''Aryakesari'', ''Mahila Ratnam'', ''Kerala Vyasan'', ''Mangalodayam'', and ''Vani Vilasam''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> He used to engage two writers to note down his recitations.<ref>{{cite book|title=Mahatcharithamaala|year=1984|page=59|author=Perunna K. N. Nair}}</ref> He never wanted to monetise his poems.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Once he quipped that he did not want to publish poems immediately after writing, but wanted to review and correct it later before sending for publication.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pandalathu Kerala Varma Thampuran|year=1932|page=110|author=A. D. Hari Sarma}}</ref>
===Mahakavyas=== Kerala Varma authored 16 major works, including two mahakavyas ''Rukmamgadacharitham'' and ''Vijayodayam''.<ref name=Encyclopedia>{{cite book|title=Encyclopaedia of Indian Literature|year=1988|publisher=Sahitya Academi|isbn=81-260-1194-7|page=1185}}</ref> Of these, ''Rukmamgadacharitham'' is considered his masterpiece.<ref name=Encyclopedia /> It was widely respected as an example of a typical mahakavya before Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer published ''Umakeralam''.<ref name=Encyclopedia /> Revealing Varma's command over the language and the medium of expression, ''Rukmamgadacharitham'' was meant for a scholarly audience.<ref name=Encyclopedia /> The book was first published in 1913 although it was completed five years before its publication.<ref name=Encyclopedia /> It contains 19 chapters.<ref name=Encyclopedia />
Both mahakavyas are considered as representations of [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical]] style.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Madasseri Madhava Warrier observed that ''Rukmamgadacharitham'' was a complete mahakavya in the old style and those who were familiar with that style would like it best.<ref name=KS>{{cite book|title=Kunchante Sesham|year=1973|page=70|author=Madasseri Madhava Warrier}}</ref> According to [[N. Krishna Pillai]], Kerala Varma's mahakavyas would astonish everybody with their word control and effortless beauty.<ref>{{cite book|title=Kairaliyude Katha|year=1986|page=279|author=N. Krishna Pillai}}</ref> [[Kumaran Asan]] reviewed ''Rukmamgadacharitham'' in ''Vivekodayam'' magazine and described it as a great work,<ref>{{cite book|title=Kerala Bhasha Sahitya Charithram: Volume 6|year=1957|page=21|author=R. Narayana Panicker}}</ref> although his review contained praises and criticism alike.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> In the preface to the book, Kerala Varma wrote that he never felt any sense of pride in writing a mahakavya, but wanted to give a place to the mythological story in Kerala literature.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pandalathinte Thiranjedutha Krithikal: Volume 1|year=1979|page=1|author=Pandalam Kerala Varma}}</ref> ''Vijayodayam'' is Kerala Varma's second mahakavya. It is a relatively smaller work as it contained only eight chapters which is the minimum requirement for a mahakavya.<ref name=Encyclopedia /> It deals with the story of Kirata and Arjuna.<ref name=Encyclopedia /> While some critics do not consider it as a mahakavya,<ref name=KSC_Ulloor_4>{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram: Volume 4|year=1974|page=721|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref> some others, most notably [[M. Leelavathy]], T. P. Balakrishnan Nair, and T. G. Madhavan Kutty rate it as a mahakavya.<ref name=Leelavathy>{{cite book|title=Malayala Kavitha Sahitya Charithram|year=1991|page=71|author=M. Leelavathy}}</ref><ref name=TPB>{{cite book|title=Mahakavya Prasthanam|year=1985|page=182|author=T. P. Balakrishnan Nair}}</ref><ref name=TGM>{{cite book|title=Mahakavya Prasthanam|year=1982|page=63|author=T. G. Madhavan Kutty}}</ref> It is believed that [[Bharavi]]'s ''[[Kirātārjunīya]]'' was Kerala Varma's inspiration to write ''Vijayodayam''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer opined that the poem was quite enchanting.<ref name=Encyclopedia /><ref name=KSC_Ulloor_4-728>{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram: Volume 4|year=1974|page=728|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref>
===Narrative poems=== Kerala Varma's narrative poems were based on either history, mythology, or pure imagination.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> ''Marthanda Devodayam'', ''Vancheesa Sathakam'', ''Sreemoola Prakasika'', and ''Sreemoolaraja Vijayam'' fall into the history based category.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> ''Saubhadra Niryanam'', ''Urmila'', ''Bheema Prabhavam'', ''Lakshmana Pravasam'', ''Ghatolkkachan'', ''Subhadra'', ''Marthya Vaibhavam'', ''Barbareekan'', ''Sayoojyam'', and ''Vibheeshaabhishekam'' can be categorised as mythology based.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> ''Bhageerathi'', ''Oru Kadha'', ''Lakshmi'', ''Oru Puravriththam'', ''Naanikkutty'', ''Chelapparambu'' are based on pure imagination.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
===Children's poetry=== Kerala Varma wrote 35 poems for children.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Kerala Varma wrote the widely popular Malayalam prayer song for children ''Daivame Kai Thozham''.<ref>{{cite web|title=DC Books – Daivame Kai Thozham|url=http://onlinestore.dcbooks.com/author/pandalam-kerala-varma|work=DC Books}}</ref> Some of his other poetry for children include ''Kalikkutty'', ''Maasangal'', ''Neram Veluthu'', ''Thathammayum Penkuttiyum'', ''Aana'', ''Ponnu Thampuran'', ''Nakshathrangal'', ''Nazhikamani'', ''Sundara Viddi'', ''Ammepaksham'', ''Kanduvo Nee'', ''Kadannalum Theneechayum'', ''Arivu'', ''Manthan Chanthayil Poyathu'', ''Jalam'', ''Oru Tharkkam'', ''Chinthikkaran'', ''Payyeppayye'', ''Kallane Killan Pidikkum'', ''Vaayu'', ''Oru Vanchippattu'', ''Kallanaya Eli'', ''Dinacharya'', ''Kakkayum Kurukkanum'', ''Pasu'', ''Palliyunarthal'', ''Prarthana'', ''Vallamkali'', and ''Ambili Ammavan''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> His poems ''Kaliyum Karyavum'', ''Payyethinnal Panayum Thinnam'', and ''Othoruma'' contain advice for children.
===Translations=== Kerala Varma translated a drama and a vyayogam from Sanskrit to Malayalam. These are ''Veni Samharam'' by Bhatta Narayana and ''Dootha Vakyam'' by [[Bhasa]]. Kerala Varma later commented that he had only respected the original authors in his translations although he never translated the works word by word.<ref name=SelectedWorks1>{{cite book|title=Pandalathinte Thiranjedutha Krithikal: Volume 1|year=1979|pages=279–280}}</ref> According to Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer, the translations were excellent and were comparable to [[Kodungallur Kunjikkuttan Thampuran]]'s translation of ''Ascharya Choodamani''.<ref name=KeralaSahityaCharithram>{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram|year=1974|page=728|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref> He further added that it required remarkable skills to translate the works of Bhatta Narayana at the same quality.<ref name=KeralaSahityaCharithram1>{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram|year=1974|page=729|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref>
===Hymns and essays=== Although his ancestral deity is [[Lord Ayyappa]], Kerala Varma wrote majority of [[hymn]]s in praise of [[Devi]].<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> ''Vani Panchakam'', ''Gauristhavam'', ''Devi Dasakam'', and ''Aryashtakam'' are such works. He also wrote hymns such as ''Ramesa Dasakam'' in praise of [[Lord Vishnu]].<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Kerala Varma wrote essays rarely. Two of his essays are ''Loka Vaichithyam'' and ''Iravan'', which are noted for their humour content and the writer's observation. ''Loka Vaichithryam'' explains the strange aspects of the world and poetry. ''Iravan'' discusses the mythological story of the tactical self-sacrifice of [[Iravan]] planned by [[Sree Krishna]] to sustain the fame of [[Arjuna]].<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Generally, Kerala Varma's works uplhold moral values.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
===Other works=== Kerala Varma's narrative poem ''Sreemoolaraja Vijayam'' is essentially lyrics for an [[Ottamthullal]], although it did not have the ease and rhythm of traditional thullal lyrics.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> This contains the chronological life events of Sree Moolam Thirunal, from birth to his 60th birthday.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> His ''Yathra Kavyam'' is a neoclassical work which narrates his personal experience of visiting Sabarimala along traditional route, following traditional custom and rituals.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> This is an incomplete work.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
===Critical reception=== Kerala Varma had a vast vocabulary. According to his biographer A. D. Hari Sarma, Kerala Varma never faced an issue in finding the right choice of word and that once he started writing, apt words used to appear as the flow of river [[Ganges]].<ref name=HariSarma>{{cite book|title=Pandalathu Kerala Varma Thampuran|year=1932|pages=43–44|author=A. D. Hari Sarma}}</ref> Vallathol described him as "Padam kondu panthaadunna Pandalam" (One who juggles with words).<ref name=MohanakshanNair>{{cite book|title=Mahakavyas of Pandalam Kerala Varma: A Study|year=2013|url=http://hdl.handle.net/10603/7532|author=A. Mohanakshan Nair}}</ref> Kerala Varma was severely criticised by Kumaran Asan in the literary periodical ''Vivekodayam''.<ref name=Vivekodayam>{{cite book|title=Kumaranasante Gadyalekhanangal: Volume 1|year=1981|page=61}}</ref> [[Joseph Mundassery]] also criticised Kerala Varma for his poetic style.<ref name=RajarajanMundasseri>{{cite book|title=Rajarajante Mattoli|year=1984|pages=57–58|author=Joseph Mundasseri}}</ref><ref name=MundasseriNanayathe>{{cite book|title=Nanayathe Meen Pidikkamo|year=1981|pages=52|author=Joseph Mundasseri}}</ref> P. V. Krishna Warrier criticised Kerala Varma in a special issue of ''Kavana Kaumudi''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Aadhunika Bhasha|journal=Kavana Kaumudi Special Issue|author=P. V. Krishna Warrier}}</ref>
Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer called Kerala Varma "Prithveesan" for his uncanny ability to write poems in Prithvi [[metre (poetry)|metre]].<ref name=Vijnanodayam>{{cite book|title=Vijnana Deepika: Moonnam Bhagam|year=1973|page=12|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref> He also remarked that Kerala Varma had absolute control over all words in Malayalam and Sanskrit.<ref name=Vijnanodayam/> [[Muloor S. Padmanabha Panicker]] compared Kerala Varma to [[Garuda]] in his ''Kaviramayanam''.<ref name=Mooloor>{{cite book|title=Muloorinte Padyakrithikal|year=1980|page=102|author=Muloor S. Padmanabha Panicker}}</ref>
==Publishing career== Kerala Varma used to publish a fortnightly periodical ''Kavana Kaumudi'', which contained poetry and contemporary issues. The periodical was published from Pandalam.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> It was the first Malayalam periodical.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> The first issue of ''Kavana Kaumudi'' was published on 4 November 1904,<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /><ref>{{cite book|title=Kerala Sahitya Charithram: Volume 4|year=1974|page=718|author=Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer}}</ref> which was 1 [[Vrischikam]] 1080 as per the [[Malayalam calendar]].<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> Kerala Varma was the owner and Chief Editor of the periodical and P. K. Narayanan Namboothiri was the publisher and manager.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The editorials in the periodical discussed social, political, and contemporary issues. These were mainly targeted at corruption and inefficiency of administration. The periodical contained advertisements also.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi>{{cite web|title=100 years of Kavana Kaumudi|url=http://www.old.kerala.gov.in/keralcalnov04/p33.pdf|work=Official Web Portal of Government of Kerala|author=Ajith Nair}}</ref> All contents in the periodical including advertisements were in poetic form.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The periodical also contained a column ''Balopadesam'' for children.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Poets like Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer opposed the idea of such a periodical initially, but later praised it and wrote in it.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
''Kavana Kaumudi'' was printed on a [[broadsheet]] with eight pages and four columns on each page.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> It was published on the 1st and 15th of all [[Malayalam calendar|Malayalam months]].<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> The earlier issues of the periodical were printed at Suvarnaratnaprabha Press, [[Kayamkulam]].<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> After the first three years, ''Kavana Kaumudi'' became a monthly publication. In 1905, the printing of the periodical was shifted to Kerala Kalpadrumam Press in [[Thrissur]], which was managed by [[Vallathol Narayana Menon]].<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> In March 1910, the printing was further shifted to Lakshmisahayam Press at [[Kottakkal]].<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> The running of ''Kavana Kaumudi'' put Kerala Varma into financial crisis.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Later, P. V. Krishna Warrier joined as the co-editor of ''Kavana Kaumudi''.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of media in Kerala|url=http://pressacademy.org/content/history-media-kerala|work=Kerala Press Academy}}</ref> Following the death of Kerala Varma, Warrier became the Chief Editor of the periodical.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> Warrier introduced a book review column in the periodical by the name ''Njangalude Vayanamuri''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Later, advertisements and book reviews started appearing in prose. Several poems from Vallathol's ''Sahitya Manjari'' and [[G. Sankara Kurup]]'s ''Sahitya Kauthukam'' were first published in ''Kavana Kaumudi''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The periodical also carried several translations of English romantic poems.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
Kerala Varma used to write poetic editorials in ''Kavana Kaumudi''. Among those who wrote on ''Kavana Kaumudi'' were Kerala Varma Valiya Koil Thampuran, [[A. R. Raja Raja Varma]], [[Punnasseri Nambi Neelakanta Sharma]], [[Kodungallur Kunjikkuttan Thampuran]], [[K. C. Kesava Pillai]], Vallathol Narayana Menon, Ulloor S. Parameswara Iyer, Muloor S. Padmanabha Panicker, Kuttippuram, and Kochunni Thampuran.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The earlier poems of Nalappattu Narayana Menon, G. Sankara Kurup, and [[V.C. Balakrishna Panicker|V. C. Balakrishna Panicker]] were also published in this periodical.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> Among the famous poets of that time, only Kumaran Asan had not written in the periodical.<ref name=MohanakshanNair />
Beside the regular issues, ''Kavana Kaumudi'' introduced special issues on nine different occasions.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> It was the first time a special issue was being printed for a Malayalam publication.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> The special issues were titled ''Bhasha Vilasam''.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The first special issue was published in 1914 and the last in 1930.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The special issues contained both poems and prose.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The first special issue contained ashtakams by famous poets based on the subject train.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /> The periodical was in print for 11 more years after the death of Kerala Varma, until it stopped in 1930.<ref name=MohanakshanNair /><ref name=KavanaKaumudi />
''Kavana Kaumudi'' is considered to have served as a unifying factor, surpassing the regional differences and parochial discriminations that existed in the early 20th century.<ref name=KavanaKaumudi /> Poet [[O. N. V. Kurup]] observed that ''Kavana Kaumudi'' ushered the poets of Kerala who were split into three regions, to a single platform.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Kavana Kaumudi: Navotdhanathinte Navarasmi|journal=Pandalam Janmasathabdi Smaranika|year=1979|page=30|author=O. N. V. Kurup}}</ref> Even Kumaran Asan who was reluctant to publish his poems through the periodical, wrote that it would not be a mistake to consider ''Kavana Kaumudi'' as a standard for understanding the prosperity of poetic skills in Malayalam.<ref>{{cite book|title=Manmaranjan Masikakal|year=1971|page=62|author=G. Priyadarsanan}}</ref> In the souvenir published during the birth centenary of Kerala Varma, poet Cherukunnam Purushothaman observed that none of the obstacles such as the complexity of the topic, demand for fast completion, or lack of time for revision or correction marred Kerala Varma's priceless editorials.<ref name=Cherukunnam>{{cite journal|title=Kavana Kaumudiyile Mughalekhanangal|journal=Pandalam Janmasathabdi Smaranika|year=1979|page=68|author=Cherukunnam Purushothaman}}</ref> Sahitya Akademi, New Delhi has published a Monograph of Pandalam Kerala Varma ( by P. Ravi Varma) in 2013
==Other notable works== *''Katha Kaumudi'' *''Sookthimaala'' *''Sabarimalayathra'' *''Shumbha Nishumbha Vadham'' *''Bhujamga Sandesham''
==Pandalam Kerala Varma Award== The Pandalam Kerala Varma Smaraka Samithi is an association set up in remembrance of the poet. The Samithi,with the sapport of Pandalathu Kottaram Nirvahaka Sanghom(Pandalam Palace Managing Commatte) offers two awards; a literary award to honour excellence in poetry and a media award to honour excellence in editorial. The award is known by the name Mahakavi Pandalam Kerala Varma Award. The award for poetry consists of a cash prize of [[Indian rupee|INR]] 15,001, plaque, and citation, and that for media consists of INR 10,001, plaque, and citation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pandalam Kerala Varma awards announced|url=http://www.hindu.com/2004/01/19/stories/2004011901290500.htm|accessdate=23 December 2013|newspaper=The Hindu}}</ref> Poets O. N. V. Kurup(Pandalam Keralavarma birth centenary award 1979), K. Ayyappa Panicker(2003), Vishnu Narayanan Namboothiri(2004), Satchidanandan(2005), Kadammanitta Ramakrishnan(2006), Akkitham Achuthan Namboothiri(2007), Sugathakumari(2008), Attoor Ravi varma(2009), D.Vinayachandran(2010), K G Sankara Pillai(2011), Ezhacherry Ramachandran(2012), Kavalam Narayana Panicker(2013),<ref>{{cite web|title=Kavalam gets Pandalam Kerala Varma award|url=http://www.kerala.com/news_kerala_Nurses_Day_/news_kerala_26/images/news_kerala_Kavalam_gets_Pandalam_24_7645.html|work=Kerala.com}}</ref> Chemmanam Chakko(2014),Neelambarur Madhusoodhanan Nair(2015), Prabha Varma(2016),Kureepuzha Sreekumar(2017), Rafeek Ahamed(2018) are the recipients of poetry award.<ref>http://www.arabnews.com/?page=9&section=0&article=91431&d=28&m=1&y=2007</ref> Media Awards were given to Editorials of Malayalam Newspapers and Piriodicals from 2003 to 2012. Madhyamam,Deepika,Mathrubhumi,Keralakaumudi,Dasabhimani.MalayalaManorama.Mangalam,Samakalika Malayalam Weekly got Media Award for Editorials.From 2013 onwards Media Award is being given to The Coulms published/telecasted by the Journalists.ThomasJacob,T.J.S George,T.N Gopakumar,Jose Panachippuram,N P Rajendran(2017)G.Sekharan Nair(2018) are the recipients.
==References== {{reflist|2}}39.Pandalam Keralavarma(Monograph),Sahitya Akademi,NewDelhi-P.Ravivarma

The '''Pentecostal Oath''' was an oath which the [[Knight]]s of [[King Arthur]]'s [[Round Table]] swore, according to [[Thomas Malory|Sir Thomas Malory's]] ''[[Le Morte d'Arthur]]''. It embodied the code of [[Chivalry]]. According to Malory's text:
« The king stablished all his knights, and gave them that were of lands not rich, he gave them lands, and charged them never to do outrageousity nor murder, and always to flee treason; also, by no mean to be cruel, but to give mercy unto him that asketh mercy, upon pain of forfeiture of their worship and lordship of King Arthur for evermore; and always to do ladies, damosels, and gentlewomen succor upon pain of death. Also, that no man take no battles in a wrongful quarrel for no law, ne for no world’s goods. Unto this were all the knights sworn of the Table Round, both old and young. And every year were they sworn at the high feast of Pentecost. »
— ''Le Morte d'Arthur'', Book III, Chapter XV
== References == * {{citation|last=Malory |first=Thomas |title=Le Morte d'Arthur |editor=Janet Cowen |place=London |publisher= Penguin |year=1969|isbn= 0-14-043044-X}}. [[Category:Knights of the Round Table|*]] [[Category:Oaths]] {{Europe-myth-stub}}

{{infobox Chinese|title=Proto-Min|t=原始閩語|s=原始闽语|p=Yuánshǐ Mǐnyǔ|poj=Goân-sí Bân-gí|buc=Nguòng-sṳ̄ Mìng-ngṳ̄|hhbuc=Ngé̤ng-sî Máng-gṳ̂|mblmc=Ngûing-sǐ Mâing-ngṳ̌|pic=Chinese tree.svg|picsize=250px|piccap=Simplified model of the evolution of varieties of Chinese }} '''Proto-Min''' is a [[comparative method (linguistics)|comparative reconstruction]] of the common ancestor of the [[Min Chinese|Min]] group of [[varieties of Chinese]]. Min varieties developed in the relative isolation of the Chinese province of [[Fujian]] and eastern [[Guangdong]], and have since spread to [[Taiwan]], southeast Asia and other parts of the world. They contain reflexes of distinctions not found in [[Middle Chinese]] or most other modern varieties, and thus provide additional data for the reconstruction of [[Old Chinese]]. [[Jerry Norman (sinologist)|Jerry Norman]] reconstructed the sound system of proto-Min from popular vocabulary in a range of Min varieties, including new data on varieties from inland Fujian. The system has a six-way manner contrast in [[stop consonant|stop]]s and [[affricate consonant|affricate]]s, compared with the three-way contrast in Middle Chinese and modern [[Wu Chinese|Wu varieties]] and the two-way contrast in most modern Chinese varieties. A two-way contrast in [[sonorant]]s is also reconstructed, compared with the single series of Middle Chinese and all modern varieties. Evidence from early loans into other languages suggests that the additional contrasts may reflect consonant clusters or [[minor syllable]]s. == Min dialects == {{main|Min Chinese}} {{Annotated image | image = China edcp relief location map.jpg | image-width = 600 | image-left = -278 | image-top = -173 | width = 225 | height = 300 | float = right | annotations = {{Annotation|161|191|'''Fujian'''}} | caption = Location of Fujian in eastern China }} The Min homeland consists of most of the province of [[Fujian]], and the adjacent eastern part of [[Guangdong]]. The area features rugged mountainous terrain, with short rivers that flow into the [[South China Sea]]. After the area was first settled by Chinese during the [[Han dynasty]], most subsequent migration from north to south China passed through the valleys of the [[Xiang River|Xiang]] and [[Gan River (Jiangxi)|Gan]] rivers to the west. Min varieties have thus developed in relative isolation.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=210, 228}} ===Separation from common Chinese=== As described in [[rime dictionary|rhyme dictionaries]] such as the ''[[Qieyun]]'' (601 AD), [[Middle Chinese]] initial [[stop consonant|stop]]s and [[affricate consonant]]s showed a three-way contrast between voiceless unaspirated, voiceless [[aspirated consonant|aspirated]] and [[voice (phonetics)|voice]]d consonants. There were four tones, with the fourth, the"entering tone", a [[checked tone]] comprising syllables ending in stops (''-p'', ''-t'' or ''-k''). This syllable structure was also found in neighbouring languages of the [[Mainland Southeast Asia linguistic area]] – [[proto-Hmong–Mien language|Proto-Hmong–Mien]], [[proto-Tai language|Proto-Tai]] and early [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] – and is largely preserved by early loans between the languages.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=54–55}} Towards the end of the first millennium AD, all of these languages experienced a tone split conditioned by initial consonants. Each tone split into an upper (''yīn'' 阴/陰) register consisting of words with voiceless initials and a lower (''yáng'' 阳/陽) register of words with voiced initials. When voicing was lost in most varieties, the register distinction became phonemic, yielding up to eight tonal categories, with a six-way contrast in unchecked syllables and a two-way contrast in checked syllables.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=52–54}} The traditional classification of [[varieties of Chinese]] distinguished seven groups according to the reflexes of Middle Chinese voiced initials in various tonal categories.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=181}} For example, voiced stops are preserved in the [[Wu Chinese|Wu]] and [[Old Xiang]] groups, have merged with aspirated or unaspirated stops depending on the tone in Mandarin, and have uniformly become aspirated stops in [[Gan Chinese|Gan]] and [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]].{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=191, 199–200, 204–205}} The distinguishing characteristic of Min varieties is that voiced stops yield both aspirated and unaspirated stops in all tonal categories. Further, the distribution is consistent across Min varieties, suggesting a common ancestor in which two types of voiced stop were distinguished.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=228–229}} Min must have diverged before two changes in other Chinese varieties (including Middle Chinese) that are not reflected in Min: * The [[Old Chinese]] finals *-jaj and *-je merged after velar initials. This merger is reflected in a change in poetic rhyme between the [[Western Han]] (206 BC to 9 AD) and Eastern Han (25–220 AD) periods.{{sfnp|Ting|1983|pp=9–10}} * Old Chinese velars [[Palatalization (sound change)|palatalized]] in certain environments during the Western Han period.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|pp=33, 79}} However, the palatalization of dental stops, which had occurred in some dialects by the Eastern Han period, is common to Middle Chinese and Min.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|p=76}} Baxter and Sagart suggest that the later part of the Proto-Min period may have overlapped with [[Early Middle Chinese]].{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|p=388}} Pointing to features of Min varieties that are also found in Hakka and Yue varieties, [[Jerry Norman (sinologist)|Jerry Norman]] suggests that the three groups are descended from a variety spoken in the lower [[Yangtze]] region during the Han period, which he calls Old Southern Chinese.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=211–214}} He argues that this dialect belonged to the group of dialects known as Wu (吳) or Jiangdong (江東) in the [[Western Jin]] period, when the writer [[Guo Pu]] (early 4th century AD) described them as quite distinct from other Chinese varieties.{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|pp=334–336}} Some of the distinctive Jiangdong words mentioned by Guo Pu appear to be preserved in modern Min varieties, including Proto-Min *giA "leech" and *lhɑnC "young fowl".{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|pp=335–336}} This language entered Fujian after the area was opened to Chinese settlement by the defeat of the [[Minyue]] state by the armies of [[Emperor Wu of Han]] in 110 BC.{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|p=328}} Norman argues that Hakka and Yue have resulted from overlays of this language by successive waves of influence from northern China.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=214}} When Chinese soldiers and settlers moved south from their homeland in the [[North China Plain]], they came into contact with speakers of [[Tai–Kadai languages|Tai–Kadai]], [[Hmong–Mien languages|Hmong–Mien]] and [[Austroasiatic languages]]. Early loans from Chinese into these languages date from around Han times and thus contain evidence of the sounds of Chinese as spoken in the south at that time.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|pp=34–37}} === Strata === Norman identifies four main layers in the vocabulary of modern Min varieties: # A non-Chinese [[stratum (linguistics)|substratum]] from the original languages of [[Minyue]], which Norman believes were [[Austroasiatic]].{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|pp=331–332}} These etymologies have been disputed by [[Laurent Sagart]], and there is no other evidence for an early Austroasiatic presence in southeast China.{{sfnp|Sagart|2008|pp=141–143}} # The earliest Chinese layer, brought to Fujian by settlers from Zhejiang to the north during the Han dynasty.{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|pp=334–336}} # A layer from the [[Northern and Southern dynasties]] period, largely consistent with the phonology of the ''[[Qieyun]]'' dictionary, which was published in 601 AD but based on earlier dictionaries that are now lost.{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|p=336}} # A [[literary and colloquial readings of Chinese characters|literary layer]] based on the [[koiné language|koiné]] of [[Chang'an]], the capital of the [[Tang dynasty]].{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|p=337}} Since the two later layers can largely be derived from the ''Qieyun'', Norman sought to focus on the earlier layers.{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|p=336}} === Subgroups === label=[[Jiangle]]|lat_deg=26.717|lon_deg=117.47 | mark=Purple pog.svg|position=left}} }} Early classifications, such as those of [[Li Fang-Kuei]] in 1937 and [[Yuan Jiahua]] in 1960, divided Min into Northern and Southern subgroups.{{sfnp|Kurpaska|2010|p=49}}{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=233}} However, in a 1963 report on a survey of Fujian, Pan Maoding and colleagues argued that the primary split was between inland and coastal groups.{{sfnp|Yan|2006|p=121}} The inland varieties are distinguished by consistently having two distinct reflexes of Middle Chinese /l/.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=233}} The two groups also have differences in their vocabulary, including their pronoun systems.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=233–234}} The coastal dialects are divided into three subgroups:{{sfnp|Kurpaska|2010|p=52}} ;[[Eastern Min]] :including [[Fuzhou]], [[Ningde]] and [[Fu'an]] in northeast Fujian ;[[Pu-Xian Min]] :including [[Putian]] and [[Xianyou County|Xianyou]] on the central Fujian coast ;[[Southern Min]] :including [[Xiamen]], [[Zhangzhou]] and [[Quanzhou]] in southern Fujian, and [[Chaozhou]], [[Jieyang]] and [[Shantou]] in eastern Guangdong They divided the inland dialects into two subgroups: ;[[Northern Min]] :including [[Jianyang District|Jianyang]], [[Jian'ou]], [[Chong'an]], [[Zhenghe County|Zhenghe]] and [[Shibei]] ;[[Central Min]] :including [[Sanming]] and [[Yong'an]] in western Fujian Several varieties in the far west of Fujian include features of Min and the neighbouring Gan and Hakka groups, making them difficult to classify. In the [[Shao-Jiang Min|Shaojiang]] dialects, spoken in the northwestern Fujian counties of [[Shaowu]] and [[Jiangle]], the reflexes of Middle Chinese voiced stops are uniformly aspirated, as in Gan and Hakka, leading some workers to assign them to one of these groups. Pan et al. described them as intermediate between Min and Hakka.{{sfnp|Yan|2006|p=122}} However, Norman showed that their tonal development could only be explained in terms of the same two classes of voiced initial assumed for Min dialects. He suggested that they were inland Min dialects that had been subject to heavy Gan or Hakka influence.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=235, 241}} Norman's student David Prager Branner argued that the varieties of [[Longyan]] and the township of Wan'an, in the southwestern part of the province, were coastal Min varieties, but outside of the three subgroups identified by Pan.{{sfnp|Branner|1999|pp=37, 78}}{{sfnp|Branner|2000|pp=115–116}} ==Initials == In a series of papers from 1973, Jerry Norman sought to reconstruct the initial consonants of proto-Min by applying the [[comparative method (linguistics)|comparative method]] to pronunciations in modern Min varieties. For this purpose, rather that the traditional approach of soliciting readings of character lists, he focussed on everyday vocabulary and excluded words of literary origin.{{sfnp|Handel|2010b|pp=28–29}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Initials of proto-Min{{sfnp|Norman|1974|p=231}}{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=28–30}} |- ! colspan="2" | ! Labial ! Dental ! Lateral ! Sibilant ! [[Alveolo-palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! Velar ! Glottal |- ! rowspan="3" | Voiceless stops
and affricates ! aspirated | ph || th || || tsh || tšh || kh || |- ! unaspirated | p || t || || ts || tš || k || ʔ |- ! "softened" | -p || -t || || -ts || -tš || -k || |- ! rowspan="3" | Voiced stops
and affricates ! aspirated | bh || dh || || dzh || džh || gh || |- ! unaspirated | b || d || || dz || dž || g || |- ! "softened" | -b || -d || || -dz || -dž || -g || |- ! rowspan="2" | Sonorants ! plain | m || n || l || || ń || ŋ || ∅ |- ! aspirated | mh || nh || lh || || (ńh)|| ŋh || |- ! rowspan="2" | Fricatives ! voiceless | || || || s || š || x || |- ! voiced | || || || z || ž || ɣ || ɦ |} The inventory of proto-Min initials differs from that of [[Middle Chinese]] (as deduced from the ''[[Qieyun]]'' rhyme book and its successors) in several ways: * Middle Chinese has two series of [[retroflex consonant|retroflex]] initials that are not found in proto-Min.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=231}}{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|pp=102, 104, 108}} * Whereas Middle Chinese obstruents have a three-way manner distinction, proto-Min has a six-way distinction: both voiced and voiceless stops may be aspirated or unaspirated, and also have an additional series that Norman called "softened".{{sfnp|Norman|1974|p=28}} * Proto-Min has two series of sonorants.{{sfnp|Norman|1973|p=231}} * Proto-Min distinguishes voiced fricatives *ɣ and *ɦ.{{sfnp|Norman|1974|p=28}} The most controversial have been the "softened" stops and affricates, so named because they have lateral or fricative reflexes in some Northern Min varieties centred on Jianyang. These initials also have distinct tonal reflexes in the Northern Min and Shaojiang groups, but have merged with unaspirated stops and affricates in coastal varieties. Other scholars have suggested that the patterns observed in northwest Fujian can be explained as a mixture of forms from neighbouring Wu, Gan and Hakka varieties, though this does not explain the regularity of the correspondences.{{sfnp|Handel|2003|pp=49–50}} In addition, the forms of many of the words in the proposed donor varieties do not match the Min reflexes, and some of the words occur only in Min.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|p=89}} Since the pioneering reconstruction of [[Bernhard Karlgren]], Old Chinese has been reconstructed by projecting the categories of Middle Chinese back onto the rhyming patterns of the ''[[Classic of Poetry]]'' and the shared phonetic components of [[Chinese characters]]. Thus Old Chinese is usually reconstructed with the same three-way manner distinction in obstruent initials found in Middle Chinese. However this does not preclude additional manner distinctions that merged in Middle Chinese, because rhyme gives no information about initials and sharing of phonetic components indicates initials with the same [[place of articulation]] but not necessarily the same manner.{{sfnp|Handel|2010a}} Several scholars have attempted to incorporate proto-Min data into their reconstructions of Old Chinese. The most systematic attempt to date is the reconstruction of Baxter and Sagart, who derive the additional initials from a number of initial consonant clusters and [[minor syllable]]s.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|pp=84–93}} === Voiceless stops and affricates === All modern Min varieties have a two-way contrast between unaspirated and aspirated voiceless stops and affricates.{{efn|Southern Min varieties also have voiced stops and affricates, which are derived from earlier nasal initials.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=237}}}} Where these initials occur with upper register tones, they are projected back into proto-Min, and correspond to unaspirated and aspirated voiceless initials in Middle Chinese. However, some Middle Chinese voiceless unaspirated initials correspond to fricatives or laterals in Northern Min, and also have a special tonal development in Northern Min and Shao–Jiang. Norman called these initials voiceless "softened" stops and affricates.{{sfnp|Norman|1973|pp=228–231}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Voiceless stop and affricate initials{{sfnp|Norman|1973|pp=229–231}}{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=32–33}}{{sfnp|Norman|1986|pp=380–382}} |- ! pMin ! Xiamen !! Fuzhou !! Jian'ou !! Jianyang !! Shaowu ! | {{linktext|割}} cut (v.), {{linktext|狗}} dog, {{linktext|缸}} jar, {{linktext|膏}} lard, {{linktext|飢}} hungry |} In loans from southern Chinese into proto-Hmong–Mien, softened obstruents are often represented by [[prenasalized consonant]]s.{{sfnp|Norman|1986|pp=381–383}} Norman suggests the proto-Min initials were also prenasalized,{{sfnp|Norman|1986|p=381}} whereas Baxter and Sagart derive them from stops preceded by [[minor syllable]]s, arguing that the intervocalic environment caused the stops to weaken to fricatives in some dialects.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|pp=88–89}} === Voiced stops and affricates === In most varieties of Chinese that have lost the voicing of Middle Chinese initials, the aspiration of the resulting initials is conditioned by tone, though the relationship varies between dialect groups. In Min varieties however, both aspirated and unaspirated voiceless initials are found in lower register tones. These initials must therefore be distinguished in proto-Min as aspirated and unaspirated voiced consonants. In Shao–Jiang these initials are uniformly aspirated, but the same distinction is reflected in the tonal development. As with the voiceless initials, there is a third group of formerly voiced initials with fricative or lateral reflexes in some Northern Min varieties, which Norman called "softened" voiced initials.{{sfnp|Norman|1973|pp=224–227}} In Eastern Min varieties, voiced unaspirated affricates typically yielded plain /s/.{{sfnp|Branner|1999|p=40}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Voiced stop and affricate initials{{sfnp|Norman|1973|pp=226–228}}{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=33–35}}{{sfnp|Norman|1986|pp=382–383}}{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=229–230}} |- ! pMin ! Xiamen !! Fuzhou !! Jian'ou !! Jianyang !! Shaowu ! ball, {{linktext|縣}} district |} There are several cases where an adjective or intransitive verb beginning with an unaspirated voiced stop is paired with a transitive verb differing only in aspiration of the voiced stop, suggesting that the contrast reflects an early morphological process.{{sfnp|Norman|1991b|pp=340–341}} Early loans from southern Chinese into proto-Hmong–Mien have prenasalized stops corresponding to both aspirated and softened voiced stops in proto-Min.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|p=88}} Baxter and Sagart derive aspirated voiced stops from tightly bound nasal preinitials in Old Chinese, and softened voiced stops from voiced stops preceded by minor syllables.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|p=88}} === Sonorants === Inland Min varieties are characterized by having two distinct reflexes of Middle Chinese /l/, which Norman labels as proto-Min *l and *lh. The two have merged in coastal varieties. In modern Southern Min varieties such as [[Hokkien]], /l/ and /n/ comprise a single phoneme, realized as /n/ before nasalized vowels and as /l/ in other syllables.{{sfnp|Norman|1973|p=231}} Two series of nasals can also be distinguished based on their tonal reflexes in Eastern Min and Shao-Jiang. They generally produce a single series of nasal initials in modern varieties except in Southern Min. In those varieties, the proto-Min initials *nh and *ŋh have become /h/ before high front vowels, *m, *n and *ŋ denasalized to *b, *l and *g respectively before oral vowels, but *mh and other occurrences of *nh and *ŋh often yield nasals in that context.{{sfnp|Norman|1991a|pp=207–208}}{{sfnp|Norman|1988|p=237}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Sonorant initials{{sfnp|Norman|1973|pp=233–235}}{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=230, 233}} |- ! pMin ! Xiamen !! Fuzhou !! Jian'ou !! Jianyang !! Shaowu ! ŋ || ŋ || ŋ/n | {{linktext|五}} five, {{linktext|外}} outside, {{linktext|月}} moon, {{linktext|玉}} jade, {{linktext|銀}} silver, {{linktext|魚}} fish, {{linktext|鵝}} goose |- | *ŋh | h || ŋ || ŋ || ŋ || ŋ/n | {{linktext|硯}} ink-stone, {{linktext|艾}} moxa, {{linktext|額}} forehead |} As the initials *lh, *nh, etc. follow the same tonal development as voiced aspirated initials throughout Min, Norman suggests that they were characterized by [[breathy voice]].{{sfnp|Norman|1991a|p=212}} In Hakka dialects, nasals appear in both lower and upper register tones, suggesting a protolanguage with both voiced and voiceless nasals. Moreover, the occurrence of these initials corresponds to the plain and aspirated nasals of proto-Min.{{sfnp|Norman|1991a|p=208}} Norman suggests that they derive from voiced and voiceless nasals in Old Southern Chinese. Further evidence for a voicing distinction comes from early loans into [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] and the [[Mienic languages|Mienic]] and [[Tai languages]].{{sfnp|Norman|1991a|pp=211–212}} Norman later abandoned the *ń initial, treating the dz-/z- initials in some Southern Min varieties as arising from *n followed by a high front vowel *i or *y.{{sfnp|Bodman|1985|p=16}}{{sfnp|Zheng|2016|pp=84–92}} A different set of voiceless resonant initials is proposed in most recent reconstructions of [[Old Chinese]], with fricative reflexes in Middle Chinese.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|p=46}} Norman suggests that Old Southern Chinese voiceless sonorants derive from sonorants preceded by voiceless consonants.{{sfnp|Norman|1973|p=233}} [[William H. Baxter|William Baxter]] and [[Laurent Sagart]] have incorporated this proposal into their reconstruction of Old Chinese.{{sfnp|Baxter|Sagart|2014|pp=171–173}} === Fricatives and others === Fricatives in upper and lower registers are assumed to derive from voiceless and voiced fricatives respectively, broadly corresponding to the voiceless and voiced fricatives of Middle Chinese.{{sfnp|Norman|1974|p=28}} Zero initials show three distinct patterns of tonal development, reconstructed as initials *ɦ, *ʔ and a proto-Min zero initial. The latter occurs only before the high front vowels *i and *y.{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=28–29}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Fricative and zero initials{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=32–35}}{{sfnp|Baxter|1992|pp=210, 834}} |- ! pMin ! Xiamen !! Fuzhou !! Jianyang !! Yongan ! {{linktext|鹽}} salt (n.), {{linktext|鹽}} to salt |- | *š | s || s || s || ʃ/s | {{linktext|使}} use, {{linktext|聲}} voice, {{linktext|蝨}} louse, {{linktext|詩}} poetry, {{linktext|身}} body |- | *ž | s fire, {{linktext|花}} flower (n.), {{linktext|虎}} tiger, {{linktext|許}} Xu (surname) |- | *ɣ | h || h || x || h/ʃ | {{linktext|園}} garden, {{linktext|巷}} lane, {{linktext|橫}} horizontal, {{linktext|雨}} rain |- | *ʔ | ∅ || ∅ || ∅ || ∅ | {{linktext|啞}} mute, {{linktext|応}} answer, {{linktext|椅}} chair, {{linktext|飲}} rice-water |- | *ɦ | ∅ || ∅ || ∅/h || ∅ | {{linktext|下}} down, {{linktext|學}} learn, {{linktext|會}} able, {{linktext|鞋}} shoe |- | *∅ | ∅ || ∅ || ∅ || ∅ | {{linktext|圓}} round, {{linktext|後}} after, {{linktext|有}} have, exist, {{linktext|羊}} goat, {{linktext|葯}} medicine, {{linktext|閑}} idle, {{linktext|黃}} yellow |} In Central Min, *s and *x merged as /ʃ/ before high front vowels.{{sfnp|Zheng|2016|p=119}} == Tones == Proto-Min had four tone classes, corresponding to the [[four tones (Middle Chinese)|four tones of Middle Chinese]]: syllables with vocalic or nasal endings belonged to class *A, *B or *C, whereas class *D consisted of the syllables ending in a stop (/p/, /t/ or /k/).{{sfnp|Norman|1973|p=223}} As with Middle Chinese and other languages of the Mainland Southeast Asia linguistic area, each of these classes split into upper and lower registers, depending on whether the original initial was voiceless or voiced.{{sfnp|Handel|2003|p=49}} When voicing was lost,{{efn|The voiced initials in modern Southern Min varieties are derived from proto-Min nasal initials.{{sfnp|Norman|1988|pp=235–236}}}} the register distinction became phonemic, yielding tone classes conventionally numbered 1 to 8, with tones 1 and 2 naming the upper and lower registers of proto-Min class A*, and so on.{{sfnp|Norman|1973|p=223}} All 8 classes are retained by the Chaozhou dialect, but some have merged in other varieties. Some northern varieties, including the Jianyang dialect, have an additional tone class (tone 9), reflecting a partial merger of tone classes that cannot be predicted from Middle Chinese forms.{{sfnp|Handel|2003|pp=55, 68–72}} {| class="wikitable" |+Reflexes of proto-Min tone classes for various types of initials{{sfnp|Norman|1973|pp=226, 229, 232–233}}{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=31–32}}{{sfnp|Handel|2003|pp=58–59}} |- ! rowspan="2" | ! colspan="8" | Tone class *A ! colspan="9" | Tone class *B ! colspan="8" | Tone class *C ! colspan="8" | Tone class *D |- ! *th !! *t !! *-t ! *n !! *nh ! *dh !! *d !! *-d ! *th !! *t !! *-t ! colspan="2" | *n !! *nh ! *dh !! *d !! *-d ! *th !! *t !! *-t ! *n !! *nh ! *dh !! *d !! *-d ! *th !! *t !! *-t ! *n !! *nh ! *dh !! *d !! *-d |- ! Shaowu | colspan="2" style="background-color:#faa" | 1 || style="background-color:#ee9" | 3 || style="background-color:#fdd" | 2 || colspan="2" style="background-color:#bcf" | 7 || colspan="2" style="background-color:#fdd" | 2 | colspan="9" style="background-color:#ee9" | 3 | colspan="2" style="background-color:#afa" | 5 || ? || style="background-color:#dfd" | 6 || colspan="2" style="background-color:#afa" | 5 || colspan="2" style="background-color:#dfd" | 6 | colspan="2" style="background-color:#bcf" | 7 || style="background-color:#ee9" | 3 || style="background-color:#dfd" | 6 || colspan="2" style="background-color:#bcf" | 7 || colspan="2" style="background-color:#dfd" | 6 |} Stop and affricate initials at other points of articulation produce the same tonal reflexes as the dental examples in the above table. Voiceless fricatives have the same tonal reflexes as voiceless aspirated and unaspirated stops. Voiced fricatives are more varied:{{sfnp|Norman|1974|pp=29–30}} * The initials *z and *ɣ have the same tonal reflexes as aspirated nasals and voiced aspirated stops. * The initial *ž follows voiced unaspirated stops. * The initial *ɦ follows softened voiced stops. The zero initial has the same tonal development as plain sonorants.{{sfnp|Norman|1974|p=30}} == Finals == Norman reconstructs proto-Min finals as consisting of: * an optional medial *i, *u or *y, * a nuclear vowel *i, *u, *y, *e, *ə, *o, *a or *ɑ, and * an optional coda *i, *u, *m, *n, *ŋ, *p, *t or *k.{{sfnp|Norman|1981|p=35}} The possible combinations were: {| class="wikitable" |+ Finals of proto-Min{{sfnp|Norman|1981|pp=35–36}} |- | || | *e | | *o | *a | |- | *i | | *ie | | *io | *ia | (*iɑ){{efn|The only example of this final, *kiɑA {{linktext|茄}} "eggplant" (Xiamen kio2) is probably a relatively late loan from a [[Tai language]].{{sfnp|Norman|1981|p=48}}}} |- | || || | (*uə){{efn|This final is found only after coronal initials.{{sfnp|Norman|1981|p=50}}}} | | *ua | |- | *y | | *ye |
